updates.canonical_current: The mistake of prioritizing a system that works well in one habitat that operates at one scale of human relationships and priorizing it in a different habitat where the scale is different
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 introduces the 'hammer and nails' metaphor: 'It's like insisting that, because a hammer is excellent for nails, everything solid must secretly be a nail. You can spend your days whacking screws and glass and dinner, growing more certain with each shattered plate that people who question hammers are enemies of progress.'
updates.proposed_merge: Add to concept: metaphor - 'The Hammer Fallacy: treating every problem as a nail because you trust your hammer'

updates.canonical_current: Four distinct scales of human relationship where different organizing systems operate naturally and effectively
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 clarifies that we already switch operating systems naturally in daily life: 'You are already "communist" with your toddler, "socialist" with your fire department, "capitalist" at the grocery store, and happily "anarchic" in your favorite group chat. You've been doing this your whole life. You just haven't been given a map that admits it.'
updates.proposed_merge: Add to definition: 'This is descriptive, not prescriptive - humans already navigate all four habitats naturally without formal instruction'

updates.canonical_current: Reframed as a human relationship system based on collective contribution and distribution according to need rather where contribution and distribution authority is highly centralized within those who sacrifice the most
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 enriches with domestic examples: 'Parents give more than they receive. Small children receive more than they give. The accounting books are gloriously uneven, and we would be horrified if they weren't.' Also explicit kitchen-table formulation: 'from each according to their ability, to each according to their need, operating at the scale of the family'
updates.proposed_merge: Add example: 'Gloriously uneven accounting books of family life (Ch 1)' - parents giving more than receiving, children receiving more than giving
updates.location: Chapter 1, Section 1, paragraphs 9-10 and Section 4 final paragraph

updates.canonical_current: Reframed as a human relationships system based on shared human needs met through commonwealth contributions to shared services that are equally distributed regardless of specific contribution amount
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 provides explicit formulation: 'collectively funded, universally available essential services like police, fire, rescue, and the military—systems we rely on together so no one burns or bleeds out alone'
updates.proposed_merge: Update book_usage to include: 'Core services where no one burns or bleeds out alone'

updates.canonical_current: Reframed as appropriate at individual-to-population level scale - a powerful engine for discovering and generating value, exchanging value across millions of individually defined value exchanges
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 provides explicit formulation: 'market-driven mechanisms that allocate resources, reward value creation, and generate surplus, and ultimately excess, at the scale of whole societies'
updates.proposed_merge: Update book_usage to include: 'Allocates resources, rewards value creation, generates surplus at societal scale'

updates.canonical_current: Reframed positively as appropriate for friendships and informal networks at the individual-to-individual scale, depending on local complex, self-adapting systems that emerge from voluntary cooperation
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 provides explicit formulation: 'what you see in your healthiest friend groups and emergent networks: from voluntary cooperation, to complex self-adapting natural systems' - also the HR Department example shows what happens when this is violated
updates.proposed_merge: Update book_usage to include: 'From voluntary cooperation, to complex self-adapting natural systems'
updates.location: Chapter 1, Section 4, definition paragraph and Section 3

updates.canonical_current: Washington DC's self-organizing carpool system where strangers share rides near initially to and from the Pentagon
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 explicitly positions the slug line as the proof that one-size-fits-all thinking fails: 'a hybrid system out of public infrastructure, private incentives, communal trust, and emergent norms. No one ideology can fully claim it. It's part market, part shared-service, part informal anarchy.'
updates.proposed_merge: Add to illustrates array: 'Hybrid nature demonstrates failure of one-ideology thinking (Ch 1)'

updates.canonical_current: The size or scope of a social grouping, ranging from intimate (individual-to-individual) to massive (individual-to-population), which determines what organizational systems work effectively
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 provides concrete scale gradient: 'a family of five, a neighborhood of five hundred, a city of five hundred thousand, and a nation of three hundred million are not just the same thing with more people. They are different kinds of creatures.'
updates.proposed_merge: Add examples with numbers: 'Family (5), Neighborhood (500), City (500,000), Nation (300,000,000) - different kinds of creatures, not just scaled versions'

updates.canonical_current: The real-world conditions and contexts in which humans operate and interact within the framework of one of the four systems, where one system takes primary view while others recede to supporting or secondary roles
updates.chapter_contribution: Chapter 1 introduces the concept of 'natural vs unnatural habitats' for systems: 'Different systems have natural habitats where they flourish—and unnatural habitats where they become monsters.'
updates.proposed_merge: Add to definition: 'Systems have natural habitats where they flourish and unnatural habitats where they become monsters'

additions.definition: The error of treating one system (capitalism, socialism, communism, or anarchy) as the universal answer applicable to all scales and contexts, rather than recognizing each as a tool appropriate to specific habitats
additions.builds_on: Common phrase 'one size fits all' applied to ideological thinking
additions.purpose: Names the pattern where people 'pick one—markets, or the state, or the tribe, or pure voluntarism—and then try to stretch it like a rubber sheet over every domain'
additions.why_new: First explicitly named in Chapter 1. Prologue demonstrated the problem; Chapter 1 names and diagnoses it
examples: Market fundamentalists applying market logic to schools, roads, or kidneys
Communitarians concluding that if families share everything, citizens should too
Statists extrapolating from fire departments to wage-setting and job allocation
Anarchists concluding that all formal authority is the problem
relates_to_canonical: System of Systems of Human Relationship Phenomena

additions.definition: The tendency to treat every problem as requiring your preferred tool: 'because a hammer is excellent for nails, everything solid must secretly be a nail'
additions.builds_on: Common aphorism 'when all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail'
additions.purpose: Provides accessible metaphor for why ideologues cannot see the limits of their preferred system
additions.why_new: First introduced in Chapter 1 as metaphorical explanation for scale errors

additions.definition: The insight that groups at different scales (family, neighborhood, city, nation) are not 'the same thing with more people' but are qualitatively different entities requiring different organizing principles
additions.builds_on: Biological concept that organisms at different scales have different properties
additions.purpose: Counters the assumption that scaling up simply means adding more people while keeping the same rules
additions.why_new: First articulated in Chapter 1 as way to explain why scale matters

additions.definition: The distinction between contexts where a system flourishes (natural habitat) versus contexts where that same system 'becomes a monster' (unnatural habitat)
additions.builds_on: Biological habitat concept - species thriving in native environment, struggling in foreign one
additions.purpose: Explains why the same system can be beautiful in one context and horrifying in another
examples: Communism: natural in family, monstrous at national scale
Capitalism: natural in marketplace, monstrous in intimate relationships
Formal authority: natural in government, monstrous in friend groups
additions.why_new: First explicitly articulated in Chapter 1. Prologue showed systems in action; Chapter 1 introduces the habitat metaphor

additions.definition: The conventional political spectrum that treats capitalism, socialism, communism, and anarchy as 'mutually exclusive identities on a single flat line' rather than as tools appropriate to different scales
additions.builds_on: Common political terminology of left/right spectrum
additions.purpose: Identifies what the book's framework replaces - teased here, developed in Chapter 2
additions.why_new: First mentioned in Chapter 1 closing as the target for critique in next chapter. Sets up Chapter 2's exploration of 'who drew it, how it took over our thinking, and what it keeps us from seeing'
relates_to_canonical: System of Systems of Human Relationship Phenomena
